title: Contributing to animovement
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven‚Äôt done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("roaldarbol/animovement", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn‚Äôt pass cleanly, ‚Äôs good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e.¬†just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Calculate kinematics
text: work movement data, often interested just animal ; ‚Äôre interested fast moves, heading etc. calculate_kinematics calculates range kinematic variables: distance: distance animal moved since last observation (simply calculated using Pythagoras‚Äô theorem) v_translation: translational velocity, like see speedometer car. direction: direction (radians) animal heading - arrow compass heading. rotation: Difference direction last observation. v_rotation: rotational velocity (rad/s).
code: # Augment all data in list df_kinematics <- df_smooth |>   calculate_kinematics() glimpse(df_kinematics) #> Rows: 37,039 #> Columns: 13 #> Groups: individual, keypoint [1] #> $ time          <dbl> 0.00000000, 0.01666667, 0.03333333, 0.05000000, 0.066666‚Ä¶ #> $ individual    <fct> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, ‚Ä¶ #> $ keypoint      <fct> centroid, centroid, centroid, centroid, centroid, centro‚Ä¶ #> $ x             <dbl> NA, 0.002538071, 0.003807107, 0.006345178, 0.008883249, ‚Ä¶ #> $ y             <dbl> NA, 0.005076142, 0.007614213, 0.012690355, 0.024111675, ‚Ä¶ #> $ confidence    <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, ‚Ä¶ #> $ d_translation <dbl> NA, NA, 0.002837650, 0.005675299, 0.011699930, 0.0056752‚Ä¶ #> $ v_translation <dbl> NA, NA, 0.1702590, 0.3405180, 0.7019958, 0.3405180, 1.22‚Ä¶ #> $ a_translation <dbl> NA, NA, NA, 10.215539, 21.688668, -21.688668, 53.234221,‚Ä¶ #> $ direction     <circular> NA, NA, 1.1071487, 1.1071487, 1.3521274, 1.1071487,‚Ä¶ #> $ d_rotation    <circular> NA, NA, NA, 0.00000000, 0.24497866, -0.24497866, -0‚Ä¶ #> $ v_rotation    <circular> NA, NA, NA, 0.000000, -14.698720, 14.698720, 3.3299‚Ä¶ #> $ a_rotation    <circular> NA, NA, NA, NA, -881.9232, 1763.8464, -682.1286, -9‚Ä¶

Based on the following method and threshold: mahalanobis (10.828). #> - For variable: d_rotation. pl_direction <- df_kinematics_clean |>   # filter(time < 20) |>   ggplot(aes(x = direction, y = v_translation)) +   stat_density_2d(     geom = "tile",     aes(fill = after_stat(density)),     n = c(40, 10),     contour = F   ) +   scale_fill_viridis_c() +   # scale_fill_gradientn(colours=rev(rainbow(32)[1:23])) +   coord_polar(     direction = -1,     start = -pi / 2   ) +   # scale_x_continuous(limits = c(0,2*pi)) +   theme_minimal()  max_coord <- max(abs(c(df_kinematics_clean$x, df_kinematics_clean$y)), na.rm = TRUE) pl_path <- df_kinematics_clean |>   ggplot(aes(x, y, colour = v_translation)) +   geom_path() +   coord_fixed() +   scale_x_continuous(limits = c(-max_coord, max_coord)) +   scale_y_continuous(limits = c(-max_coord, max_coord)) +   scale_colour_viridis_c() +   theme_minimal()  pl_path + pl_direction +   plot_layout(guides = "collect") #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_path()`). #> Warning: Removed 27649 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range #> (`stat_density2d()`).

title: Mission & Scope
text: primary goal animovement package offer streamlined standardised workflow analysing animal movement data, syntax designed integrate seamlessly tidyverse ecosystem. Animal movement, whether produced humans animals, crucial navigating interacting environment. Understanding movements great interest scientists diverse fields ethology, behavioral ecology, biomechanics, neuroscience. numerous tools available quantifying movement, data produce ‚Äî whether video tracking software hardware like treadmills, trackballs, accelerometers ‚Äî often lack standardised approach analysis. makes difficult easily process compare movement data across different studies platforms. animovement package addresses gap establishing standardised workflow processing movement data, leveraging common data formats (collaboration movement) offering ‚Äúrecipe‚Äù streamlined data analysis.

title: Mission & Scope
text: core, animovement processes trajectories individual keypoints time. spatial position individual represented one (centroid) keypoints (pose), provided 1D (x), 2D (x, y), 3D (x, y, z) coordinates. sequentially collected positions form tracks time. neuroscience ethology, tracks commonly generated : Pose estimation tools like DeepLabCut SLEAP, track multiple keypoints individual. Centroid tracking software like TRex idtracker.ai, focuses single point (centroid) per individual. Treadmills trackballs, record movement belt ball, serving proxies 1D (treadmill) 2D (trackball) centroid tracking. vision provide intuitive accessible workflow using familiar tidyverse syntax. animovement designed handle data various sources, supporting 1D, 2D, 3D tracking single multiple individuals. practice, goal make possible derive meaningful insights movement data fewer 10 lines code. example:
code: library(animovement) movement_summary <- read_deeplabcut(path) |>   clean_tracks() |>   calculate_kinematics() |>   clean_kinematics() |>   calculate_statistics()

code: library(here, quietly = TRUE) #> here() starts at /home/runner/work/animovement/animovement here::i_am("vignettes/articles/read-trackball.Rmd") #> here() starts at /home/runner/work/animovement/animovement filepath_1 <- here("tests", "testthat", "data", "single", "opticalflow_sensor_1.csv") filepath_2 <- here("tests", "testthat", "data", "single", "opticalflow_sensor_2.csv") filepaths <- c(filepath_1, filepath_2)  # These might be something like: here("data", "trackball", "sensor_1", "trackballdata_100.csv") for you! df <- read_trackball(   filepaths,   setup = "of_free",   col_time = 4,   sampling_rate = 60,   distance_scale = 394 )

title: Read trackball data
text: use: File names contain little information. scenario use spreadsheet keep track files go together. .xlsx file contains correct pairs file names. Let‚Äôs begin reading inspecting file. can import data, one experiment . , use package make file management easier.
code: library(readxl) metadata_path <- here("inst", "extdata", "multi", "trackball_filenames.xlsx") metadata_file <- read_xlsx(metadata_path) metadata_file #> # A tibble: 2 √ó 4 #>   identity date                filename_a                      filename_b        #>   <chr>    <dttm>              <chr>                           <chr>             #> 1 A100     2021-08-05 00:00:00 GB_COM6_2021-08-05T15_37_55.csv GB_COM7_2021-08-‚Ä¶ #> 2 A100     2021-08-12 00:00:00 GB_COM6_2021-08-12T15_37_55.csv GB_COM7_2021-08-‚Ä¶ library(tibble) library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE)  # First, we'll create an empty data frame which we'll read our data into df <- tibble()  # Then we loop through the rows in the metadata file for (i in 1:nrow(metadata_file)) {   # Like before, change the path to match your local file structure   file_primary <- here("inst", "extdata", "multi", metadata_file$filename_a[i])   file_secondary <- here("inst", "extdata", "multi", metadata_file$filename_b[i])    # Then we'll read all the file   df_temp <- read_trackball(     c(file_primary, file_secondary),     setup = "of_free",     col_time = 4,     sampling_rate = 60,     distance_scale = 394   )    # And we can add other metadata, such as the identity and date to distinguish between experiments   df_temp <- df_temp |>     mutate(       id = metadata_file$identity[i],       date = metadata_file$date[i]     )    # Finally, we bind the data together   df <- bind_rows(df, df_temp) }

title: Add Centroid to Movement Data ‚Äî add_centroid
text: data data frame containing movement tracking data following required columns: individual: Identifier tracked subject keypoint: Factor specifying tracked points time: Time values x: x-coordinates y: y-coordinates confidence: Confidence values tracked points include_keypoints Optional character vector specifying keypoints use centroid calculation. NULL (default), keypoints used unless exclude_keypoints specified. exclude_keypoints Optional character vector specifying keypoints exclude centroid calculation. NULL (default), keypoints excluded unless include_keypoints specified. centroid_name Character string specifying name centroid keypoint (default: "centroid")

title: Add Centroid to Movement Data ‚Äî add_centroid
text: data frame structure input, additional keypoint representing centroid. centroid's confidence values set NA.

title: Add Centroid to Movement Data ‚Äî add_centroid

title: Align a time series with a reference series using cross-correlation ‚Äî align_timeseries
code: # Create two artificially shifted sine waves t <- seq(0, 10, 0.1) reference <- sin(t) signal <- sin(t - 0.5)  # Signal delayed by 0.5 units  # Align the delayed signal with the reference aligned <- align_timeseries(signal, reference)  # Plot to verify alignment plot(t, reference, type = "l", col = "black") lines(t, aligned, col = "red", lty = 2)

title: Classify Movement States Based on Stability Analysis ‚Äî classify_by_stability
text: speed Numeric vector speed velocity measurements. velocity provided, absolute values used automatically window_size Number measurements consider calculating variance (default: 30) min_stable_period Minimum length required stable period (default: 30) tolerance Tolerance variance stable periods (default: 0.1, must 0 1) refine_transitions Whether refine state transitions using stability detection (default: TRUE) min_low_state_duration Minimum duration low activity states; shorter periods merged using majority context (default: 0, merging) min_high_state_duration Minimum duration high activity states; shorter periods merged using majority context (default: 0, merging) search_window far look movement transitions refining (default: 90) stability_window Window size checking movement stabilized (default: 10) stability_threshold Maximum variance allowed stable state (default: 0.5) return_type function return "factor" ("high"/"low") "numeric" (1/0) (default: "numeric")

title: Classify Movement States Based on Stability Analysis ‚Äî classify_by_stability
text: Numeric vector length input: 1: High activity state 0: Low activity state NA: Unable classify (usually due missing data)

title: Classify Movement States Based on Stability Analysis ‚Äî classify_by_stability
text: classification process follows key steps: Stability Detection: Identifies stable periods movement data Uses longest stable period establish baseline low activity State Classification: Sets activity threshold based baseline period Classifies periods deviate baseline stability high activity Optional Refinement: refine_transitions = TRUE, examines transitions states find precise start/end points using stability detection Short duration states can filtered based min_low_state_duration min_high_state_duration parameters using majority context approach

what: Apply Butterworth Highpass Filter to Signal ‚Äî filter_highpass
title: Apply Butterworth Highpass Filter to Signal ‚Äî filter_highpass
text: function applies highpass Butterworth filter signal using forward-backward filtering (filtfilt) achieve zero phase distortion. Butterworth filter maximally flat passband, making ideal many signal processing applications.

title: Apply Butterworth Highpass Filter to Signal ‚Äî filter_highpass
code: filter_highpass(   x,   cutoff_freq,   sampling_rate,   order = 4,   na_action = c("linear", "spline", "stine", "locf", "value", "error"),   keep_na = FALSE,   ... )

title: Apply Butterworth Highpass Filter to Signal ‚Äî filter_highpass
text: x Numeric vector containing signal filtered cutoff_freq Cutoff frequency Hz. Frequencies value passed, frequencies attenuated. 0 sampling_rate/2. sampling_rate Sampling rate signal Hz. Must least twice highest frequency component signal (Nyquist criterion). order Filter order (default = 4). Controls steepness frequency rolloff: - Higher orders give sharper cutoffs may introduce ringing - Lower orders give smoother transitions less steep rolloff - Common values practice 2-8 - Values 8 rarely used due numerical instability na_action Method handle NA values filtering. One : - "linear": Linear interpolation (default) - "spline": Spline interpolation smoother curves - "stine": Stineman interpolation preserving data shape - "locf": Last observation carried forward - "value": Replace constant value - "error": Raise error NAs present keep_na Logical indicating whether restore NAs original positions filtering (default = FALSE) ... Additional arguments passed replace_na(). Common options include: - value: Numeric value replacement na_action = "value" - min_gap: Minimum gap size interpolate/fill - max_gap: Maximum gap size interpolate/fill

title: Apply Butterworth Highpass Filter to Signal ‚Äî filter_highpass
text: Numeric vector containing filtered signal

title: Apply Butterworth Highpass Filter to Signal ‚Äî filter_highpass
text: Butterworth filter response falls -6*order dB/octave. cutoff frequency corresponds -3dB point filter's magnitude response. Common Applications: Removing baseline drift: Use low cutoff (0.1-1 Hz) EMG analysis: Use moderate cutoff (10-20 Hz) Motion artifact removal: Use application-specific cutoff Parameter Selection Guidelines: cutoff_freq: Choose based lowest frequency want preserve order: guidelines lowpass_filter Common values field: ECG processing: order=2, cutoff=0.5 Hz EEG analysis: order=4, cutoff=1 Hz Mechanical vibrations: order=2, cutoff application-specific Missing Value Handling: function uses replace_na() internally handling missing values. See ?replace_na detailed information method parameters. NAs can optionally restored original positions filtering using keep_na = TRUE.

title: Apply Butterworth Highpass Filter to Signal ‚Äî filter_highpass
text: Butterworth, S. (1930). Theory Filter Amplifiers. Wireless Engineer, 7, 536-541.

title: Apply Butterworth Highpass Filter to Signal ‚Äî filter_highpass
code: # Generate example signal with drift t <- seq(0, 1, by = 0.001) drift <- 0.5 * t  # Linear drift signal <- sin(2*pi*10*t)  # 10 Hz signal x <- signal + drift  # Add some NAs x[sample(length(x), 10)] <- NA  # Basic filtering with linear interpolation for NAs filtered <- filter_highpass(x, cutoff_freq = 2, sampling_rate = 1000)  # Using spline interpolation with max gap constraint filtered <- filter_highpass(x, cutoff_freq = 2, sampling_rate = 1000,                            na_action = "spline", max_gap = 3)  # Replace NAs with zeros before filtering filtered <- filter_highpass(x, cutoff_freq = 2, sampling_rate = 1000,                            na_action = "value", value = 0)  # Filter but keep NAs in their original positions filtered <- filter_highpass(x, cutoff_freq = 2, sampling_rate = 1000,                            na_action = "linear", keep_na = TRUE)

Must least twice highest frequency component signal (Nyquist criterion). na_action Method handle NA values filtering. One : - "linear": Linear interpolation (default) - "spline": Spline interpolation smoother curves - "stine": Stineman interpolation preserving data shape - "locf": Last observation carried forward - "value": Replace constant value - "error": Raise error NAs present keep_na Logical indicating whether restore NAs original positions filtering (default = FALSE) ... Additional arguments passed replace_na(). Common options include: - value: Numeric value replacement na_action = "value" - min_gap: Minimum gap size interpolate/fill - max_gap: Maximum gap size interpolate/fill

text: Numeric vector containing filtered signal

title: Apply FFT-based Highpass Filter to Signal ‚Äî filter_highpass_fft
text: FFT-based filtering applies hard cutoff frequency domain. can advantageous : Precise frequency selection Batch processing long signals Cases sharp frequency cutoffs desired Common Applications: Removing baseline drift: Use low cutoff (0.1-1 Hz) EMG analysis: Use moderate cutoff (10-20 Hz) Motion artifact removal: Use application-specific cutoff Limitations: May introduce ringing artifacts Assumes periodic signal (can cause edge effects) Less suitable real-time processing Missing Value Handling: function uses replace_na() internally handling missing values. See ?replace_na detailed information method parameters. NAs can optionally restored original positions filtering using keep_na = TRUE.

title: Apply FFT-based Highpass Filter to Signal ‚Äî filter_highpass_fft
code: # Generate example signal with drift t <- seq(0, 1, by = 0.001) drift <- 0.5 * t  # Linear drift signal <- sin(2*pi*10*t)  # 10 Hz signal x <- signal + drift  # Add some NAs x[sample(length(x), 10)] <- NA  # Basic filtering with linear interpolation for NAs filtered <- filter_highpass_fft(x, cutoff_freq = 2, sampling_rate = 1000)  # Using spline interpolation with max gap constraint filtered <- filter_highpass_fft(x, cutoff_freq = 2, sampling_rate = 1000,                                na_action = "spline", max_gap = 3)  # Replace NAs with zeros before filtering filtered <- filter_highpass_fft(x, cutoff_freq = 2, sampling_rate = 1000,                                na_action = "value", value = 0)  # Filter but keep NAs in their original positions filtered <- filter_highpass_fft(x, cutoff_freq = 2, sampling_rate = 1000,                                na_action = "linear", keep_na = TRUE)  # Compare with Butterworth filter butter_filtered <- filter_highpass(x, 2, 1000)

title: Apply Butterworth Lowpass Filter to Signal ‚Äî filter_lowpass

title: Apply Butterworth Lowpass Filter to Signal ‚Äî filter_lowpass
code: filter_lowpass(   x,   cutoff_freq,   sampling_rate,   order = 4,   na_action = c("linear", "spline", "stine", "locf", "value", "error"),   keep_na = FALSE,   ... )

title: Apply Butterworth Lowpass Filter to Signal ‚Äî filter_lowpass
text: x Numeric vector containing signal filtered cutoff_freq Cutoff frequency Hz. Frequencies value passed, frequencies attenuated. 0 sampling_rate/2. sampling_rate Sampling rate signal Hz. Must least twice highest frequency component signal (Nyquist criterion). order Filter order (default = 4). Controls steepness frequency rolloff: - Higher orders give sharper cutoffs may introduce ringing - Lower orders give smoother transitions less steep rolloff - Common values practice 2-8 - Values 8 rarely used due numerical instability na_action Method handle NA values filtering. One : - "linear": Linear interpolation (default) - "spline": Spline interpolation smoother curves - "stine": Stineman interpolation preserving data shape - "locf": Last observation carried forward - "value": Replace constant value - "error": Raise error NAs present keep_na Logical indicating whether restore NAs original positions filtering (default = FALSE) ... Additional arguments passed replace_na(). Common options include: - value: Numeric value replacement na_action = "value" - min_gap: Minimum gap size interpolate/fill - max_gap: Maximum gap size interpolate/fill

title: Apply Butterworth Lowpass Filter to Signal ‚Äî filter_lowpass
text: Numeric vector containing filtered signal

title: Apply Butterworth Lowpass Filter to Signal ‚Äî filter_lowpass
text: Butterworth filter response falls -6*order dB/octave. cutoff frequency corresponds -3dB point filter's magnitude response. Parameter Selection Guidelines: cutoff_freq: Choose based frequency content want preserve sampling_rate: match data collection rate order: order=2: Gentle rolloff, minimal ringing (~12 dB/octave) order=4: Standard choice, good balance (~24 dB/octave) order=6: Steeper rolloff, ringing (~36 dB/octave) order=8: steep, may significant ringing (~48 dB/octave) Note: low cutoff frequencies (<0.001 Nyquist), order automatically reduced 2 maintain stability. Common values field: Biomechanics: order=2 4 EEG/MEG: order=4 6 Audio processing: order=2 8 Mechanical vibrations: order=2 4 Missing Value Handling: function uses replace_na() internally handling missing values. See ?replace_na detailed information method parameters. NAs can optionally restored original positions filtering using keep_na = TRUE.

title: Apply Butterworth Lowpass Filter to Signal ‚Äî filter_lowpass
text: Butterworth, S. (1930). Theory Filter Amplifiers. Wireless Engineer, 7, 536-541.

title: Apply Butterworth Lowpass Filter to Signal ‚Äî filter_lowpass
code: # Generate example signal: 2 Hz fundamental + 50 Hz noise t <- seq(0, 1, by = 0.001) x <- sin(2*pi*2*t) + 0.5*sin(2*pi*50*t)  # Add some NAs x[sample(length(x), 10)] <- NA  # Basic filtering with linear interpolation for NAs filtered <- filter_lowpass(x, cutoff_freq = 5, sampling_rate = 1000)  # Using spline interpolation with max gap constraint filtered <- filter_lowpass(x, cutoff_freq = 5, sampling_rate = 1000,                           na_action = "spline", max_gap = 3)  # Replace NAs with zeros before filtering filtered <- filter_lowpass(x, cutoff_freq = 5, sampling_rate = 1000,                           na_action = "value", value = 0)  # Filter but keep NAs in their original positions filtered <- filter_lowpass(x, cutoff_freq = 5, sampling_rate = 1000,                           na_action = "linear", keep_na = TRUE)

what: Apply Savitzky-Golay Filter to Movement Data ‚Äî filter_sgolay
title: Apply Savitzky-Golay Filter to Movement Data ‚Äî filter_sgolay
text: function applies Savitzky-Golay filter smooth movement data preserving higher moments (peaks, valleys) better moving average filters. implementation uses zero-phase filtering prevent temporal shifts data.

title: Apply Savitzky-Golay Filter to Movement Data ‚Äî filter_sgolay
code: filter_sgolay(   x,   sampling_rate,   window_size = ceiling(sampling_rate/10) * 2 + 1,   order = 3,   preserve_edges = FALSE,   na_action = "linear",   keep_na = FALSE,   ... )

title: Apply Savitzky-Golay Filter to Movement Data ‚Äî filter_sgolay
text: x Numeric vector containing movement data filtered sampling_rate Sampling rate data Hz. Must match data collection rate (e.g., 60 60 FPS motion capture). window_size Window size samples (must odd). Controls amount smoothing. Larger windows give smoothing may -attenuate genuine movement features. Default automatically calculated sampling_rate/10 (rounded nearest odd number). order Polynomial order (default = 3). Controls well filter preserves higher-order moments data: - order=2: Preserves position, velocity (good smooth movements) - order=3: Also preserves acceleration (good movement data) - order=4: Also preserves jerk (good quick movements) - order=5: Maximum preservation (may retain much noise) preserve_edges Logical indicating whether use progressively smaller windows beginning end signal reduce edge effects (default = FALSE). Note: affects signal endpoints, internal discontinuities. na_action Method handle NA values filtering. One : - "linear": Linear interpolation (default) - "spline": Spline interpolation smoother curves - "locf": Last observation carried forward - "value": Replace constant value - "error": Raise error NAs present keep_na Logical indicating whether restore NAs original positions filtering (default = FALSE) ... Additional arguments passed replace_na()

title: Apply Savitzky-Golay Filter to Movement Data ‚Äî filter_sgolay
text: Numeric vector containing filtered movement data

title: Apply Savitzky-Golay Filter to Movement Data ‚Äî filter_sgolay
text: Savitzky-Golay filter fits successive polynomials sliding windows data. approach preserves higher moments data better simple moving averages Butterworth filters, making particularly suitable movement data preserving features like peaks valleys important. Edge Handling: preserve_edges = TRUE, function uses progressively smaller windows near beginning end signal reduce endpoint distortion. affects signal endpoints - detect handle internal discontinuities sharp events within data. Parameter Selection Guidelines: window_size: 60 FPS: 5-15 frames (83-250ms) quick movements, 15-31 slow movements 120 FPS: 7-21 frames (58-175ms) quick movements, 21-51 slow movements 500 FPS: 25-75 frames (50-150ms) quick movements, 75-151 slow movements default window_size = sampling_rate/10 works well typical human movement. order: order=2: Smooth movements, position analysis order=3: movement analysis (default) order=4: Quick movements, sports analysis order=5: quick movements, impact analysis Note: order must less window_size Common values application: Gait analysis (60 FPS): window_size=15, order=3 Sports biomechanics (120 FPS): window_size=21, order=4 Impact analysis (500 FPS): window_size=51, order=4 Posture analysis (60 FPS): window_size=31, order=2

title: Apply Savitzky-Golay Filter to Movement Data ‚Äî filter_sgolay
text: Savitzky, ., & Golay, M.J.E. (1964). Smoothing Differentiation Data Simplified Least Squares Procedures. Analytical Chemistry, 36(8), 1627-1639.

title: Apply Savitzky-Golay Filter to Movement Data ‚Äî filter_sgolay
code: # Generate example movement data: smooth motion + noise t <- seq(0, 5, by = 1/60)  # 60 FPS data x <- sin(2*pi*0.5*t) + rnorm(length(t), 0, 0.1)  # Basic filtering with default parameters (60 FPS) filtered <- filter_sgolay(x, sampling_rate = 60)  # Adjusting parameters for quick movements filtered_quick <- filter_sgolay(x, sampling_rate = 60,                                window_size = 11, order = 4)  # High-speed camera data (500 FPS) with larger window filtered_high <- filter_sgolay(x, sampling_rate = 500,                               window_size = 51, order = 3)

text: Palshikar, G. (2009). Simple Algorithms Peak Detection Time-Series. Proc. 1st Int. Conf. Advanced Data Analysis, Business Analytics Intelligence.

title: Find Peaks in Time Series Data ‚Äî find_peaks
code: # Basic usage with default window size (3) x <- c(1, 3, 2, 6, 4, 5, 2) find_peaks(x) #> [1]    NA  TRUE FALSE  TRUE FALSE  TRUE    NA  # With larger window size find_peaks(x, window_size = 5)  # More stringent peak detection #> [1]    NA    NA FALSE  TRUE FALSE    NA    NA  # With minimum height find_peaks(x, min_height = 4, window_size = 3) #> [1]    NA FALSE FALSE  TRUE FALSE  TRUE    NA  # With plateau handling x <- c(1, 3, 3, 3, 2, 4, 4, 1) find_peaks(x, plateau_handling = "middle", window_size = 3)  # Middle of plateaus #> [1]    NA FALSE  TRUE FALSE FALSE  TRUE  TRUE    NA find_peaks(x, plateau_handling = "all", window_size = 5)     # All plateau points #> [1]    NA    NA FALSE FALSE FALSE  TRUE  TRUE    NA  # With missing values x <- c(1, 3, NA, 6, 4, NA, 2) find_peaks(x) #> [1] NA NA NA NA NA NA NA  # Usage with dplyr library(dplyr) data_frame(   time = 1:10,   value = c(1, 3, 7, 4, 2, 6, 5, 8, 4, 2) ) %>%   mutate(peaks = find_peaks(value, window_size = 3)) #> Warning: `data_frame()` was deprecated in tibble 1.1.0. #> ‚Ñπ Please use `tibble()` instead. #> # A tibble: 10 √ó 3 #>     time value peaks #>    <int> <dbl> <lgl> #>  1     1     1 NA    #>  2     2     3 FALSE #>  3     3     7 TRUE  #>  4     4     4 FALSE #>  5     5     2 FALSE #>  6     6     6 TRUE  #>  7     7     5 FALSE #>  8     8     8 TRUE  #>  9     9     4 FALSE #> 10    10     2 NA

what: Find Troughs in Time Series Data ‚Äî find_troughs
title: Find Troughs in Time Series Data ‚Äî find_troughs
text: Identifies troughs (local minima) numeric time series, options filter troughs based height prominence. function handles missing values (NA) appropriately compatible dplyr's mutate. Includes flexible handling plateaus adjustable window size trough detection.

title: Find Troughs in Time Series Data ‚Äî find_troughs
code: find_troughs(   x,   max_height = Inf,   min_prominence = 0,   plateau_handling = c("strict", "middle", "first", "last", "all"),   window_size = 3 )

title: Find Troughs in Time Series Data ‚Äî find_troughs
text: x Numeric vector containing time series data max_height Maximum height threshold troughs (default: Inf) min_prominence Minimum prominence threshold troughs (default: 0) plateau_handling String specifying handle plateaus. One : "strict" (default): points plateau troughs "middle": Middle point(s) plateau troughs "first": First point plateau trough "last": Last point plateau trough "": points plateau troughs window_size Integer specifying size window use trough detection (default: 3). Must odd >= 3. Larger values detect troughs wider ranges.

title: Find Troughs in Time Series Data ‚Äî find_troughs
text: logical vector length input : TRUE indicates confirmed trough FALSE indicates non-trough NA indicates trough status determined due missing data

title: Find Troughs in Time Series Data ‚Äî find_troughs
text: function uses sliding window algorithm trough detection (window size specified window_size parameter), combined region-based prominence calculation method similar described Palshikar (2009).

title: Find Troughs in Time Series Data ‚Äî find_troughs
text: function optimized use dplyr's mutate noisy data, consider using larger window_size smoothing series trough detection Adjust max_height min_prominence filter unwanted troughs Choose plateau_handling based specific needs Larger window_size values result stringent trough detection

title: Find Troughs in Time Series Data ‚Äî find_troughs
text: point considered trough lowest point within window (default window_size 3 compares point immediate neighbors). first last (window_size-1)/2 points series troughs marked NA. Larger window sizes identify troughs dominate wider range, typically resulting fewer troughs detected.

title: Find Troughs in Time Series Data ‚Äî find_troughs
text: Prominence measures much trough stands relative surrounding values. calculated height lowest maximum trough lower troughs (end series lower troughs exist) minus height trough.

title: Find Troughs in Time Series Data ‚Äî find_troughs
text: Plateaus (sequences identical values) handled according plateau_handling parameter: strict: points plateau considered troughs (traditional behavior) middle: plateaus odd length, middle point marked trough. plateaus even length, two middle points marked troughs. first: first point plateau marked trough last: last point plateau marked trough : Every point plateau marked trough Note cases, plateau must still qualify trough relative surrounding window (.e., lower points window).

title: Find Troughs in Time Series Data ‚Äî find_troughs
text: function uses following rules handling NAs: point NA, trough (returns NA) point window NA, trough status determined (returns NA) prominence calculations, stretches NAs handled appropriately minimum window_size points required; shorter series return NAs

title: Find Troughs in Time Series Data ‚Äî find_troughs
text: Palshikar, G. (2009). Simple Algorithms Peak Detection Time-Series. Proc. 1st Int. Conf. Advanced Data Analysis, Business Analytics Intelligence.

title: Find Troughs in Time Series Data ‚Äî find_troughs
code: # Basic usage with default window size (3) x <- c(5, 3, 4, 1, 4, 2, 5) find_troughs(x) #> [1]    NA  TRUE FALSE  TRUE FALSE  TRUE    NA  # With larger window size find_troughs(x, window_size = 5)  # More stringent trough detection #> [1]    NA    NA FALSE  TRUE FALSE    NA    NA  # With maximum height find_troughs(x, max_height = 3, window_size = 3) #> [1]    NA FALSE FALSE  TRUE FALSE  TRUE    NA  # With plateau handling x <- c(5, 2, 2, 2, 3, 1, 1, 4) find_troughs(x, plateau_handling = "middle", window_size = 3)  # Middle of plateaus #> [1]    NA FALSE  TRUE FALSE FALSE  TRUE  TRUE    NA find_troughs(x, plateau_handling = "all", window_size = 5)     # All plateau points #> [1]    NA    NA FALSE FALSE FALSE  TRUE  TRUE    NA  # With missing values x <- c(5, 3, NA, 1, 4, NA, 5) find_troughs(x) #> [1] NA NA NA NA NA NA NA  # Usage with dplyr library(dplyr) data_frame(   time = 1:10,   value = c(5, 3, 1, 4, 2, 1, 3, 0, 4, 5) ) %>%   mutate(troughs = find_troughs(value, window_size = 3)) #> # A tibble: 10 √ó 3 #>     time value troughs #>    <int> <dbl> <lgl>   #>  1     1     5 NA      #>  2     2     3 FALSE   #>  3     3     1 TRUE    #>  4     4     4 FALSE   #>  5     5     2 FALSE   #>  6     6     1 TRUE    #>  7     7     3 FALSE   #>  8     8     0 TRUE    #>  9     9     4 FALSE   #> 10    10     5 NA

title: Group every N observations together ‚Äî group_every
code: ## Group by every 5 seconds df_time <- data.frame(   time = seq(from = 0.02, to = 100, by = 1/30), # time at 30Hz, slightly offset   y = rnorm(3000)) # random numbers  df_time |>   group_every(seconds = 5) |> # group for every 5 seconds   dplyr::summarise(time = min(time), # summarise for time and y                    mean_y = mean(y)) |>   dplyr::mutate(time = floor(time)) # floor to get the round second number #> # A tibble: 20 √ó 3 #>      bin  time     mean_y #>    <dbl> <dbl>      <dbl> #>  1     0     0 -0.0669    #>  2     1     5 -0.128     #>  3     2    10  0.000244  #>  4     3    15  0.0100    #>  5     4    20 -0.131     #>  6     5    25 -0.161     #>  7     6    30  0.0575    #>  8     7    35  0.0127    #>  9     8    40  0.166     #> 10     9    45 -0.0199    #> 11    10    50 -0.0209    #> 12    11    55 -0.0108    #> 13    12    60  0.0113    #> 14    13    65 -0.0000138 #> 15    14    70 -0.00843   #> 16    15    75  0.129     #> 17    16    80  0.0124    #> 18    17    85  0.0706    #> 19    18    90  0.0656    #> 20    19    95  0.0229     # Group every n observations df <- data.frame(   x = seq(1:1000),   y = rnorm(1000))  df |>   group_every(n = 30) |> # group every 30 observations together   dplyr::summarise(mean_x = mean(x),                    mean_y = mean(y)) #> # A tibble: 34 √ó 3 #>      bin mean_x  mean_y #>    <dbl>  <dbl>   <dbl> #>  1     1   15.5 -0.100  #>  2     2   45.5 -0.0723 #>  3     3   75.5 -0.232  #>  4     4  106.  -0.379  #>  5     5  136.  -0.243  #>  6     6  166.  -0.0330 #>  7     7  196.  -0.174  #>  8     8  226.  -0.187  #>  9     9  256.   0.0321 #> 10    10  286.  -0.0391 #> # ‚Ñπ 24 more rows

title: Read trackball data ‚Äî read_trackball
text: paths Two file paths, one sensor (although one allowed fixed setup, of_fixed). setup type experimental setup used. Expects either of_free, of_fixed fictrac (soon). sampling_rate Sampling rate tells function long time integrate . sampling rate 60(Hz) mean windows 1/60 sec used integrate . col_time column contains information time. Can specified either column number (numeric) name column one (character). either datetime (POSIXt) seconds (numeric). col_dx Column name x-axis values col_dy Column name y-axis values ball_calibration running of_fixed experiment, may (necessary) provide calibration factor. factor number recorded 360 degree spin. can use calibrate_trackball function get number. Alternatively, provide ball_diameter distance_scale (e.g. mouse dpcm). ball_diameter running of_fixed experiment, ball diameter needed together either ball_calibration distance_scale. distance_scale using computer mice, might getting unit-less data . However, computer mice factor called "dots-per-cm", can use convert estimates centimeters. distance_unit unit used. distance_scale also used, unit scaled data. E.g. trackball data optical flow sensors, can use mouse dots-per-cm (dpcm) 394 setting distance_unit = "cm" distance_scale = 394. verbose FALSE (default), suppress warning messages.
